qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I mainly use my phone for calling the shop owner, customers, and family members. Sometimes customers call to ask if items are available. I also use WhatsApp to receive messages about work timings or payments. In the evening, I watch YouTube videos for entertainment and news.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, I share my phone with my wife and sometimes with my children. They use it to make calls or watch videos. I don’t mind sharing because we are family, but I feel uneasy if someone else uses it.

qa.question: What apps and features do you frequently use?
qa.answer: I mostly use phone calls, WhatsApp, YouTube, and the camera. I use the camera to take photos of shop items if the owner asks. I don’t use many other apps because I don’t understand them well.

qa.question: Do you read app permissions before allowing them?
qa.answer: No, I don’t read them. I cannot understand English properly. When the phone asks for permission, I just press ‘Allow’ so the app works.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app is safe to use?
qa.answer: If the shop owner, my friends, or my children say it is okay, then I use it. I don’t download apps on my own. Usually, someone else installs them for me.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted messages, photos, or apps for privacy?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete photos after work is done, especially if they are related to customers or shop items. I also delete WhatsApp messages sometimes when my phone storage becomes full.

qa.question: What do you do before giving your phone for repair?
qa.answer: I remove the SIM card and memory card. I don’t know how to delete everything properly, so I just hope the repair person does not check my personal photos or messages.

qa.question: Have you asked someone for help with phone problems?
qa.answer: Yes, I usually ask my children or the shop owner. Sometimes I go to a local mobile repair shop. I feel worried because they can see my phone, but I don’t have any other option.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I trust my wife and children. I don’t trust strangers or people from the shop with personal matters.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes, I save some contacts with short names so others don’t understand who they are. For example, I don’t save full names.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: I helped my wife learn how to answer WhatsApp calls and send voice messages. I didn’t explain permissions because I don’t understand them myself.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how to do that. I didn’t know apps could use those things without opening them.

qa.question: What do you do when you get warning messages on your phone?
qa.answer: I get scared and close the message. I usually show it to my children or ask someone who knows phones better.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think the app can see those photos or contacts. I don’t know what happens after that.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, because family photos and WhatsApp messages are there. I worry someone might look at them.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your photos or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Once, the repair person opened my gallery saying storage is full. I felt uncomfortable but didn’t say anything.

qa.question: Do you use a lock screen on your phone?
qa.answer: Yes, I use a pattern lock. My wife and children also know it.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones?
qa.answer: I don’t know the difference. I use whatever apps others tell me to use.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand phone settings?
qa.answer: I ask my children or sometimes the shop owner.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my children tell me not to share OTPs and not to answer unknown calls. I follow what they say.

scenarios.Broken Phone: Before giving my phone for repair, I remove the SIM card. If my children are there, I ask them to delete photos. Otherwise, I just give it and worry.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If my wife or children use my phone, I don’t mind. If a message comes, I check it later.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I don’t install apps myself. I ask my children or friends to install them.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I help them make calls and answer calls. I don’t explain about app permissions.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: I only make the call I need and return the phone quickly.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I ask my children to delete everything before giving the phone to someone else.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t know about cloud backup. If deleted photos come back, I will be very worried.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: I don’t use free WiFi. I only use mobile data.
scenarios.Lottery Call: I receive such calls sometimes. I cut the call and block the number.
scenarios.Emergency Bank Transfer: If someone asks for money urgently, I call them directly or ask my children before doing anything.
